quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You're much better doing the hard thing, which is hard to scale, finding the thousands of micro influencers that have an audience where your product maybe is actually useful.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A contrarian influencer marketing playbook: prioritize many micro-influencers with real product fit over a few big creators.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We would have an idea in the morning, come up with some sort of functional prototype, recruit a bunch of people that are legitimately good prospective users, but have zero skin in the game, ship fast so people can start playing with it.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A practical rapid-experimentation loop for early product development that forces real user feedback quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In the afternoon, we're already running pretty full scale experiment.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Sets an aggressive tempo standard for validating ideas within hours rather than weeks.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You start actually hearing other people describe their usage of the product. We can also watch them struggle.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A reminder to rely on observed behavior and user language to uncover usability issues and true value.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: They just hit 100 million ARR in just over two years.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete growth benchmark that frames the scale and speed of Gamma’s execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta helps companies of all sizes get complying fast and stay that way with industry-leading AI automation and continuous monitoring.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights an operational approach to compliance: automate and continuously monitor rather than treat it as a one-time project.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta also helps you complete security questionnaires up to five times faster so that you can win bigger deals sooner.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Connects compliance work directly to revenue outcomes by speeding up a common sales bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The result, according to a recent IDC study, Vanta customers slashed over $500,000 a year and are three times more productive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides concrete ROI and productivity data points to justify investing in compliance automation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: My life would be so incredibly complicated to hire people internationally, to pay people on time, and in their local currencies, and to answer their HR questions 24/7.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical example of the hidden operational overhead of distributed teams that tooling can remove.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They do your human resources right so that you can do right by your people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable principle for delegating HR operations to free leaders to focus on employee experience and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: JPMorgan ads and setting the episode agenda
quotes.text: So my goal with this conversation is essentially do an anthropological study of a really successful AI startup.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Offers a useful framing for founders/operators: treat a successful company as a “study” to extract repeatable patterns across milestones.

quotes.topic_title: JPMorgan ads and setting the episode agenda
quotes.text: So we started the company back in 2020. This is peak pandemic. And even fundraising was just so different. So all of the fundraising was done over Zoom.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A concrete example of adapting go-to-market and fundraising tactics to constraints—useful for thinking about operating under unusual market conditions.

quotes.topic_title: JPMorgan ads and setting the episode agenda
quotes.text: And so for us, we're first time founders. I was actually living in London at the time, and so different time zone. I had to do all of my pitches at night.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Highlights a practical reality of fundraising logistics and the need to design a sustainable cadence around personal constraints.

quotes.topic_title: JPMorgan ads and setting the episode agenda
quotes.text: I would basically find this little corner between the kitchenette and the laundry room to kind of set up shot, far enough from the kids so they wouldn't be woken up.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Memorable, specific illustration of scrappy execution—optimize for progress over perfect conditions.

quotes.topic_title: Founding story and investor rejection lesson
quotes.text: And so for me, I started thinking about, if we're going to succeed in this category, we're going to really have to think about growth from the very beginning.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A concrete lesson from rejection: in hard, incumbent-dominated markets, you must design for growth from day one rather than bolting it on later.

quotes.topic_title: Founding story and investor rejection lesson
quotes.text: And so we really kind of made this sort of promise to ourselves, that as we continue to build, growth was going to be critically important.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Highlights an explicit operating commitment that can guide prioritization and product decisions throughout the build phase.

quotes.topic_title: Founding story and investor rejection lesson
quotes.text: And so my thing to your audience is that I don't come from a growth background. So if I can learn growth, anybody can learn growth.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Encourages practitioners to treat growth as a learnable skill rather than a specialized background requirement.

quotes.topic_title: Founding story and investor rejection lesson
quotes.text: I think especially in this sort of market, hyper competitive, oftentimes very crowded, it's going to be essential.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A clear takeaway about market conditions: the more crowded the space, the more essential growth competency becomes.

quotes.topic_title: Founding story and investor rejection lesson
quotes.text: Just to share some stats, I know this is going to be by the time this launches, this will be out, but you guys are at over 100 million ARR now, worth over $2 billion.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific outcome metric that underscores how far the company scaled despite early investor skepticism.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product-market fit through organic pull
quotes.text: And then we'd look at signups, and you'd get that initial spike in signups, and then they sort of flatten out. We were still getting new users every day, but it was clear we didn't have strong word of mouth. There wasn't strong organic virality. And so if we just kind of played things out, we knew that the product wasn't going to grow on its own. Something was missing there. We didn't have that strong word of mouth so that the product could just continue growing.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A concrete diagnostic for PMF: a launch spike without sustained word-of-mouth indicates the product won’t grow on its own.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product-market fit through organic pull
quotes.text: We are going to do everything we possibly can to make the first 30 seconds of the product feel magical. The moment you land into the product, it has to be great, and it has to be so great that someone that goes through that onboarding is going to tell all their friends.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A practical methodology: optimize the first 30 seconds/onboarding to trigger sharing and organic pull.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product-market fit through organic pull
quotes.text: And so we relaunched, this is end of March 2023. And all of a sudden, we'd go from a few hundred signups a day to now first day it was like a couple thousand, and then the next day would be like 5,000 signups, and then 10,000 signups a day, and then 20,000 signups a day.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Specific growth data showing the impact of the onboarding rebuild and relaunch.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product-market fit through organic pull
quotes.text: And we weren't doing any sort of marketing, no advertising. It was all sort of organic word of mouth virality of the product, people using the product and sharing it with others, where we for the first time really felt this pull. We didn't have to do anything. Product was just growing.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Defines PMF as “pull” where growth happens without marketing effort—an operational test practitioners can use.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product-market fit through organic pull
quotes.text:
I think the temptation would've been, hey, let's just spend more on ads or spend more on marketing. Because we'll just fuel the top of the funnel and everything else will work itself out.

(00:12:53):
I think that would've been a trap. I think that would've led us down to this path of trying to brute force our way into product market fit. And it would just always be sort of a fleeting sort of destination. We would never actually arrive.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A contrarian warning: using paid acquisition to mask weak word-of-mouth can prevent ever reaching true PMF.

quotes.topic_title: Word-of-mouth machine and shareability loops
quotes.text: Yeah, I mean my one piece of advice is when you're early on, your mindset should almost be like you're trying to create a word of mouth machine. If you can get that part right, everything else becomes significantly easier.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A clear early-stage mental model: prioritize building a “word of mouth machine” as the core growth engine before layering on other tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Word-of-mouth machine and shareability loops
quotes.text: And then you should see that in all the leads that are coming through or people coming through through your prospects and your existing customers. If you're not seeing a healthy chunk of those leads come through that way, I would go back. I'm like, why? Why is that not happening?
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A practical PMF diagnostic: a “healthy chunk” of leads should be referral-driven; if not, treat it as a root-cause investigation.

quotes.topic_title: Word-of-mouth machine and shareability loops
quotes.text: So I think for us it's a combination of both. And ideally, you have other ways where word of mouth or organic virality can happen in your product. So by nature of usage, like it's being shared.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A product design principle: embed sharing into the natural workflow so virality happens as a byproduct of usage, not a bolted-on feature.

quotes.topic_title: Word-of-mouth machine and shareability loops
quotes.text: We basically had an internal mantra that, we go back to the first 30 seconds, we want it to be dead simple for someone to create content, we want to be dead simple for them to share it. And everything we did for that first 30 seconds, or call it the first few minutes, is remove friction so that they can do both of those things. Create and share.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: An execution methodology: optimize the first 30 seconds/minutes to remove friction from the create→share loop, increasing spread and activation.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding vanity metrics and the Product Hunt trap
quotes.text: Yeah, I mean part of being a founder is being as self-aware as you can and be your own worst critic.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A reminder that founders need disciplined self-critique to avoid being misled by feel-good signals.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding vanity metrics and the Product Hunt trap
quotes.text: And so oftentimes you want to have these vanity metrics that feel good to celebrate, and you should celebrate. But you should know when it's a vanity metric versus is this core to our growth engine?
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A practical lens for separating morale-boosting wins from metrics that actually drive sustainable growth.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding vanity metrics and the Product Hunt trap
quotes.text: If this number goes up, does it mean the product is working?
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A simple test practitioners can apply to any KPI to validate whether it reflects real product value.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding vanity metrics and the Product Hunt trap
quotes.text: But it wasn't good enough to actually have this sort of feeling that we had a core growth engine we could just invest in and get better and better. That wasn't there yet.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway that even major launch accolades may not indicate a compounding growth loop.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding vanity metrics and the Product Hunt trap
quotes.text: Yeah, it was still like we were still getting signups. They were coming through. But you could just tell there wasn't this building momentum.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A concrete example of how signups can mask the absence of momentum and retention-driven growth.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding magic: first 30 seconds and one egg
quotes.text: And so for us, we thought about, okay, the first moment someone walks through our door, dropping into the product, what is something we can give them? Can we shorten that time to value as much as possible?
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A practical onboarding lens: optimize the very first moment around minimizing time-to-value.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding magic: first 30 seconds and one egg
quotes.text: And I think one approach is you think about new users as you almost have a cynical view of them. You have to think about them being selfish, vain, and lazy, right? They're coming in, they have no desire to learn a new tool.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A contrarian but useful mental model for designing onboarding around real user motivation and low patience.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding magic: first 30 seconds and one egg
quotes.text: And so what can you give them in that first 30 seconds that earns you the next 30 seconds and then the next 30 seconds?
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A memorable framework for earning attention in increments rather than assuming users will stick around.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding magic: first 30 seconds and one egg
quotes.text: There's this thing from consumer advertising, which is you throw a consumer one egg, they can probably catch it. You throw them four or five eggs, they're probably going to drop all of them.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A sticky metaphor for focusing onboarding messaging on one core value prop instead of many features.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding magic: first 30 seconds and one egg
quotes.text: We only had 12 people building. It's like we couldn't make an entirely revamp the entire product. We knew that we had to least put all of our energy into one spot, and so we made that coming into the door, come through the door, make that moment feel magical so that we can do a little bit more over time.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A concrete constraint-driven example of prioritizing a single high-leverage onboarding moment when resources are limited.

quotes.topic_title: Original insight: reimagining slides and AI timing
quotes.text: So I just remember this late night trying to prepare for next day's meeting, trying to format and figure out the right layout, and spending hours just trying to get the sort of look and feel right, rather than the content itself.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Highlights the core user pain: time gets wasted on formatting instead of substance, a strong signal for product opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Original insight: reimagining slides and AI timing
quotes.text: And for me, that just felt completely backwards. I should be spending 90% of the time on the content, 10% maybe on the design and formatting.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Provides a practical time-allocation heuristic practitioners can use to evaluate whether a workflow/tool is serving the real job-to-be-done.

quotes.topic_title: Original insight: reimagining slides and AI timing
quotes.text: And so the question just was what if there's a better way? What if we could reimagine this format from the ground up?
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Models a first-principles approach: don’t optimize legacy workflows—rethink the medium itself when constraints are arbitrary.

quotes.topic_title: Original insight: reimagining slides and AI timing
quotes.text: And so we thought about, okay, if we had different building blocks, different primitives, so you're not locked into the fixed 16 by nine slide, what could we offer to users?
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A concrete product methodology: change the primitives (building blocks) to unlock new UX and capabilities beyond legacy formats.

quotes.topic_title: Original insight: reimagining slides and AI timing
quotes.text: Great timing. It wasn't part of the original vision, although the spirit was there, which is we wanted to make it incredibly fast and effortless for people to create content.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Counterintuitive lesson on strategy: anchor on an enduring user outcome (speed/effortlessness) and let new tech (AI) become the accelerant later.

quotes.topic_title: Early user acquisition: friends, Product Hunt, and reality
quotes.text: And I think early on, your friends want to do you a favor, so they're going to try the product. They're also going to lie to you. They're going to tell you how great it is. And then you look at the usage and nobody's coming back.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Highlights the common trap of mistaking friendly feedback for real retention, pushing practitioners to measure usage instead of compliments.

quotes.topic_title: Early user acquisition: friends, Product Hunt, and reality
quotes.text: And so I think our first 100 was sort of gradually hard-earned post the product launch, people learning like, okay, this is kind of becoming a little bit more useful.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Emphasizes that early user acquisition can be slow and earned through incremental usefulness rather than a single growth hack.

quotes.topic_title: Early user acquisition: friends, Product Hunt, and reality
quotes.text: Usage was still pretty episodic, so they weren't coming back every week.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A concrete retention diagnostic practitioners can apply: identify whether usage is episodic vs. habitual to guide product iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Early user acquisition: friends, Product Hunt, and reality
quotes.text: And then I do think the moment post the AI launch is where all of a sudden we saw that sort of organic growth happening, people coming back to the product regularly.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Connects product step-change (AI launch/onboarding) to organic growth and repeat usage, underscoring retention as a growth lever.

quotes.topic_title: Early user acquisition: friends, Product Hunt, and reality
quotes.text: And so that's where, it wasn't even the first hundred, it was like probably the first 10,000 users all came within a pretty short time period after that initial launch.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A specific growth data point showing how a successful relaunch can compress acquisition from hundreds to ~10,000 quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Provocative launch tweet and Paul Graham boost
quotes.text: And honestly, we kind came up with kind of a clickbaity sort of tweet. It was like the most valuable skill in business is about to become obsolete.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A concrete example of using a deliberately provocative hook to drive attention for a launch without relying on Product Hunt.

quotes.topic_title: Provocative launch tweet and Paul Graham boost
quotes.text: And so for me, it was almost like my first learning moment, going back to what does founder led marketing even mean? It means how do you actually break through the noise?
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Defines founder-led marketing as the founder’s responsibility to engineer attention and engagement, not just build the product.

quotes.topic_title: Provocative launch tweet and Paul Graham boost
quotes.text: Part of that is copywriting, part of that is storytelling. Part of that is just having even the right visuals to share.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A practical breakdown of the core components founders can directly improve to increase distribution of their launches.

quotes.topic_title: Provocative launch tweet and Paul Graham boost
quotes.text: And so it was for me kind of a moment just understanding, hey, to kind of do this right, you kind of have to do things that maybe you're not super comfortable with, but it makes a difference.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that effective marketing often requires founders to lean into uncomfortable tactics that still align with their narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Provocative launch tweet and Paul Graham boost
quotes.text: Yeah. It's interesting how much a comment can increase the distribution of a tweet versus them retweeting it or quote tweeting it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a tactical distribution insight: high-profile replies/comments can outperform retweets in driving reach.

quotes.topic_title: Founder-led marketing: craft, practice, and platform fit
quotes.text: And then that allows you to actually have a higher bar when you start working with other marketers, or in this case for us, working with influencers.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Founder-led marketing as a way to build taste and standards so you can evaluate and direct marketers/creators effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Founder-led marketing: craft, practice, and platform fit
quotes.text: And I think too many founders will then just say, they'll write something that just feels so much like an ad, and then they'll give it to a creator to help amplify. And then that just never works.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that “hand it to a creator” fails if the underlying message is ad-like rather than native and compelling.

quotes.topic_title: Founder-led marketing: craft, practice, and platform fit
quotes.text: My advice is definitely just to try to start small. Don't let it become so intimidating that you just don't get started.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A practical starting principle for founders who feel they don’t have time or confidence to create content consistently.

quotes.topic_title: Founder-led marketing: craft, practice, and platform fit
quotes.text: For me, it was like just having a notepad or a Google Doc around in the beginning where I would just constantly jot down, okay, this is something I learned or something I observed or something that worked well, something that was unintuitive but worked, and just start creating a log of that.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A repeatable workflow: maintain an “idea log” of lessons/observations to turn into posts later.

quotes.topic_title: Founder-led marketing: craft, practice, and platform fit
quotes.text: And I think what I've learned is, even for LinkedIn versus Twitter, the audiences want different things. And so you almost have to then have different tones of voices or even nuggets or sharing.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Platform-fit guidance: tailor content and tone to the audience instead of cross-posting the same message everywhere.

quotes.topic_title: Creating goodwill through value-first content
quotes.text: For me, it's usually two times of the day, very first thing in the morning and last thing at night.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A concrete scheduling tactic for consistently creating content by anchoring it to low-distraction bookends of the day.

quotes.topic_title: Creating goodwill through value-first content
quotes.text: And then I think in the mornings it's about where are you finding inspiration, what are topics you're energized by? And then I think at night it's about reflection.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A simple morning/night split that turns content creation into a repeatable system: ideate when fresh, write from lived experience when reflective.

quotes.topic_title: Creating goodwill through value-first content
quotes.text: I think with founder-led marketing, it's almost this mindset of you want to give people a ton of content, maybe it's a value in the content, so you're sharing something, maybe some secret tactic or you're giving them something where inherently there's value in it, and in exchange you sort of get goodwill back.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A value-exchange model for marketing that reframes content as a trade for goodwill rather than immediate conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Creating goodwill through value-first content
quotes.text: And I think that's magic, where you kind of bank the goodwill for a long period of time by providing just a ton of value with no expectation of anything immediately in return.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: A counterintuitive long-game approach: build an audience by over-delivering value before ever asking for attention on product launches.

quotes.topic_title: Creating goodwill through value-first content
quotes.text: Nobody wants to read your shit, so you have to try really hard to make it really good.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A blunt quality bar that explains why most content fails and pushes practitioners to compete for attention with higher craft and usefulness.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling past $10M ARR: rebrand as growth unlock
quotes.text: And I think the main blocker of my mind that I started feeling was that our initial brand was holding us back.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Highlights a practical scaling inflection point where brand becomes a growth constraint, not just a cosmetic layer.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling past $10M ARR: rebrand as growth unlock
quotes.text: So one, our initial brand was almost more of a placeholder brand because we created it the moment we incorporated the company, which was again late 2020, beginning of 2021, where we needed something so that as we built, we could at least share it with people.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Gives a concrete methodology: start with a “placeholder brand” to ship early, then revisit once you hit scale.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling past $10M ARR: rebrand as growth unlock
quotes.text: And when I think about something that could be scalable, it's almost like you can take the ingredients of a brand and replicate it a ton, this DNA is something where you can imagine creating tons of content around and all feeling pretty cohesive.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model of “brand DNA” as replicable ingredients that enable high-volume, cohesive output.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling past $10M ARR: rebrand as growth unlock
quotes.text: And so you're going from tiny pieces of content to all of a sudden every week we're testing thousands of pieces of creative.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Provides a specific scaling example that explains why brand systems must support massive creative throughput.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling past $10M ARR: rebrand as growth unlock
quotes.text: It ended up being way more expensive, way more time consuming than I would've imagined. But I think coming on the other side of it being the right investment, feeling that that was the right time to do it.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Counterbalances rebrand skepticism with a candid cost/effort reality check and a timing lesson around ~$10M ARR.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to influencer marketing deep dive
quotes.text: I think a lot of founders assume that with influencer marketing it's almost like turnkey.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Challenges the common belief that influencer marketing can be delegated and run hands-off once budget is allocated.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to influencer marketing deep dive
quotes.text: And I think the reality is, going back to this founder-led marketing mindset is like, well, you're going to set yourself up for success if you actually are super involved in that entire process.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Frames influencer marketing as an extension of founder-led marketing, emphasizing deep founder involvement as a success factor.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to influencer marketing deep dive
quotes.text: So for us, what this meant was all the initial influencers I onboarded manually myself.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Gives a concrete operational tactic: founders personally onboarding early influencers rather than outsourcing immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to influencer marketing deep dive
quotes.text: I would jump on a call with each one of them so that they understood what Gamma represented, how to use the product.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Provides a specific, repeatable step (1:1 calls) to ensure creators understand the product and brand before posting.

quotes.topic_title: Transition to influencer marketing deep dive
quotes.text: You want to be able to have them tell your story but in their voice, right? And they can't do that if you're not willing to put in that investment.
quotes.speaker: Grant Lee
quotes.context: Highlights the tradeoff: authentic creator storytelling requires upfront time investment from the team/founder.
